questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with dilated tortuous veins in the leg. He had a history of trauma 10 years back in the same limb. On examination, the dilated tortuous vein showed pulsatility. Most likely diagnosis in this patient will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AV fistula

 

An arteriovenous (AV) fistula is an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein. The history of trauma in the same limb suggests a possible traumatic AV fistula. The presence of pulsatility in the veins is a key indicator, as it implies that arterial pressure is being transmitted to the veins. This is not typical for varicose veins, aneurysms, or hemangiomas, making AV fistula the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicose vein: Varicose veins are typically dilated, tortuous veins caused by incompetent valves but do not show pulsatility.

 

Option B. Aneurysm: Aneurysms involve arterial dilation and do not present with pulsatile veins.

 

Option C. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign tumors of blood vessels, usually presenting as a mass and not associated with pulsatile veins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of trauma with the presence of dilated tortuous veins showing pulsatility strongly indicates an arteriovenous fistula due to the transmission of arterial pulsation to the veins

questions.text: Type 2 lepra reaction is which type of hypersensitivity reaction? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

Explanation:

 

Type 2 lepra reaction (also known as erythema nodosum leprosum, ENL) is mediated by a Type III hypersensitivity reaction. In this type of reaction:

 

  • Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • This reaction occurs in lepromatous leprosy due to a sudden increase in circulating Mycobacterium leprae antigens that form immune complexes with antibodies.
  • The immune complexes cause tissue damage, resulting in tender erythematous nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation.
  • Key Features of Type III Hypersensitivity:
  • Immune complex-mediated (IgG or IgM antibodies bind to soluble antigens).
  • Complement activation and neutrophilic inflammation.
  • Examples: Type 2 lepra reaction, serum sickness, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Type I Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Mediated by IgE antibodies, causing mast cell degranulation.
  • Seen in allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, and atopic conditions (e.g., urticaria, asthma).

 

Option B) Type II Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Involves cytotoxic antibodies (IgG or IgM) binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to cell destruction via complement or ADCC (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).
  • Examples: Hemolytic anemia, Goodpasture syndrome, Rh incompatibility.

 

Option D) Type IV Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Cell-mediated immunity involving T-lymphocytes and macrophages.
  • Delayed onset (48-72 hours) and seen in tuberculin skin tests, contact dermatitis, and granuloma formation.
  • Type I lepra reaction (reversal reaction) is an example of Type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum) is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition. It presents with tender nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation and is commonly associated with lepromatous leprosy.

questions.text: A gymnasium owner found that people drank ice tea while exercising in his gym. He further mentioned that the subsequent weight loss was solely due to ice tea. This is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spurious association

 

A spurious association occurs when a relationship between two variables is falsely inferred, often due to the presence of a confounding variable. In this case, the gym owner observed that people drank ice tea while exercising and then experienced weight loss. However, the weight loss is actually due to the exercise, not the ice tea.

 

The gym owner incorrectly attributed the weight loss solely to the consumption of ice tea, which is a classic example of a spurious association—where the real cause (exercise) is overlooked or ignored, and an unrelated factor (ice tea) is wrongly identified as the cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct association: This would imply a straightforward cause-and-effect relationship; such as exercise leading directly to weight loss. This is not applicable here because the claim was that ice tea, not exercise, caused the weight loss.

 

Option B. Indirect association: An indirect association occurs when the relationship between two variables is mediated by one or more additional variables. For example, exercise might lead to increased metabolism, which in turn leads to weight loss. This is not applicable in this scenario because the weight loss is directly due to exercise, not mediated by another factor like ice tea.

 

Option D. No association: This would imply that there is no relationship at all between the variables. However, in this scenario, the gym owner has incorrectly claimed an association, which makes it a spurious association rather than no association.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A spurious association occurs when a relationship is wrongly inferred between two variables due to a confounding factor. In this case, the gym owner incorrectly attributed weight loss to ice tea consumption rather than the true cause, which is exercise.

questions.text: A man eats 3 cones of ice cream. After some time, he starts feeling more colder ears than the central parts of his body. Which part of the brain is responsible for thermo-regulation? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypothalamus

 

The hypothalamus is responsible for regulating body temperature, among other vital functions. It serves as the body's thermostat, receiving input from temperature receptors in the body and initiating appropriate responses to maintain homeostasis. When the body temperature deviates from the set point, the hypothalamus triggers mechanisms to adjust the temperature. For instance, if the body is too cold, the hypothalamus may initiate heat production processes such as shivering.

 

In the scenario described, the man starts feeling colder in his ears compared to the central parts of his body. This is because the hypothalamus is actively managing the body's response to the cold stimuli (the ice cream), directing blood flow to the core to maintain essential organ temperature, which can result in peripheral parts like the ears feeling colder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalamus: The thalamus is primarily involved in relaying sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and regulating consciousness, sleep, and alertness. It does not play a direct role in thermoregulation.

 

Option C. Amygdala: The amygdala is involved in emotional processing, including fear and pleasure responses, and memory formation, but it does not regulate body temperature.

 

Option D. Caudate nuclei: The caudate nuclei are part of the basal ganglia and are involved in various functions such as motor control and learning, but they are not involved in thermoregulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypothalamus is the part of the brain responsible for regulating body temperature and maintaining homeostasis.

choices.text: Intermediate filaments

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intermediate filaments

 

The clinical scenario given here describes alcoholic hepatitis. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies and they contain intermediate filaments.

 

i) Hepatocellular necrosis:

 

ii) Mallory bodies or alcoholic hyaline:

 

These are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions found in swollen and ballooned hepatocytes. They represent aggregates of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments (prekeratin). They are best seen with connective tissue stains such as Masson's trichrome and chromophobe aniline blue, as well as immunoperoxidase methods.

 

Mallory bodies are highly suggestive of, but not specific for, alcoholic hepatitis, as they can be found in a variety of other conditions, including primary biliary cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis, cholestatic syndromes, Wilson's disease, intestinal bypass surgery, focal nodular hyperplasia, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

iii) Inflammatory response: primarily polymorphs with some scattered mononuclear cells.

 

iv) Fibrosis: Pericellular and perivenular fibrosis that appears web-like or chickenwire-like. This is also termed as creeping collagenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: Actin is a type of microfilament found in the cytoskeleton of cells, but it is not the primary component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Option C. Microtubules: Microtubules are another component of the cytoskeleton, but they are not the primary component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Option  D. Fibronectin: Fibronectin is a high-molecular-weight glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to membrane-spanning receptor proteins such as integrins. It is not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chronic alcoholic patients with alcoholic hepatitis, Mallory-Denk bodies are a characteristic histopathological finding. These intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions consist of aggregated cytoskeletal intermediate filaments, specifically prekeratin.

questions.text: In the presented spirometry image, what term corresponds to the point labelled as 'F'? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced vital capacity

 

Explanation:

 

The spirometry diagram illustrates various lung volumes and capacities –

 

The point labelled 'F' corresponds to the forced vital capacity (FVC), which is the maximum amount of air a person can forcibly exhale from their lungs after taking the deepest breath possible. It includes the tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV).

 

In this context:

 

  • Tidal Volume (TV): The amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breathing (A).
  • Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV): The additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation (B).
  • Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): The additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation (C).
  • Forced Vital Capacity (FVC): The total volume of air that can be exhaled forcefully after taking a deep breath (TV + IRV + ERV) (F).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Expiratory reserve volume: This is the additional volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled after normal exhalation, represented by 'C' in the diagram.

 

Option C. Total lung capacity: This is the total volume of air in the lungs after a maximum inhalation, including the residual volume. It is not represented by 'F'.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: This is the total volume of air that can be inhaled after a normal exhalation, represented by 'D' in the diagram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spirometry diagram

questions.text: 15-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. CRP and ESR were elevated, and urinalysis showed RBCs. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgA vasculitis

 

IgA vasculitis, formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), is a small-vessel vasculitis characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes. It commonly presents in children and young adults with a classic tetrad of symptoms: palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis or arthralgia, and renal involvement (hematuria). The elevated CRP and ESR indicate an inflammatory process, and the presence of RBCs in the urine suggests renal involvement, all of which are consistent with IgA vasculitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis: This condition, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is a type of vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels and is characterized by granulomas, often affecting the respiratory tract and kidneys. It does not typically present with palpable purpura.

 

Option C. Microscopic polyangiitis: This is another small-vessel vasculitis that can present with renal involvement and systemic symptoms, but it does not typically present with palpable purpura and is not specifically associated with IgA deposition.

 

Option D. Behçet's disease: Behçet's disease is a vasculitis that can affect vessels of all sizes and presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions. Palpable purpura and the specific symptom triad in this case are not characteristic of Behçet's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) commonly presents with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain, and renal involvement, and is characterized by IgA immune complex deposition.

questions.text:
Which of the features given below is of a male pelvis?

 

  1. Triangular obturator foramen

  2. U-shaped pubic angle

  3. Everted ischial tuberosity

  4. Large greater sciatic notch

  5. Large acetabulum

  6. Deep preauricular sulcus
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only 5   

 

Large acetabulum: The acetabulum in males is generally larger to support a greater range of motion and the weight of a more muscular body.

 

Other Features:

 

1. Triangular obturator foramen: Typically seen in males.

 

2. U-shaped pubic angle: This is more characteristic of the female pelvis, which has a wider pubic angle to facilitate childbirth.

 

3. Everted ischial tuberosity: This is more common in females.

 

4. Large greater sciatic notch: More pronounced in females.

 

6. Deep preauricular sulcus: More commonly seen in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between male and female pelvis

questions.text: The vertical and horizontal fracture of nasal septum is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet and Jarjaway fracture

 

  • Chevallet fracture - Fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

 

 

  • Jarjaway fracture - Fracture line starts just above the anterior nasal spine and runs horizontally backward just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer.

 

 

Tripod fracture – is zygomatic fracture. Zygoma is separated into three processes. Fracture line passes through zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus and the zygomaticotemporal suture

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Citelli fracture - This does not pertain to the nasal septum but rather involves other cranial structures.

 

Option C. Tripod fracture - This is a zygomatic fracture where the zygoma is separated into three processes. The fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture, unrelated to the nasal septum fractures.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important classifications in the context of nasal injuries, describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively. Understanding these fracture types aids in accurate diagnosis and management of nasal trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 166

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcutaneous sumatriptan

 

Subcutaneous sumatriptan is shown to be effective in treating acute attacks of cluster headaches. The reference indicates that oral sumatriptan is not effective, whereas subcutaneous sumatriptan has been proven beneficial. Intranasal sumatriptan and intranasal zolmitriptan also are shown to be effective.

 

Additionally, 100% oxygen therapy at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute is effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral sumatriptan: Oral sumatriptan has not been shown to be effective in treating acute cluster headache attacks.

 

Option C. 100% oxygen at 6 L/minute: Although 100% oxygen is a treatment option, the effective rate is at least 12 liters per minute, making 6 L/minute inadequate.

 

Option D. 100% oxygen at 8 L/minute: Similar to the previous option, 8 L/minute is below the effective rate of 12 liters per minute required for treating acute cluster headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is subcutaneous sumatriptan, and 100% oxygen therapy should be administered at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute for effectiveness.

questions.text: A woman presents with lesions on the inner thighs and peri-anal region. They are nodular, 4-6 mm in size, and appear pale. The histopathological image shows multiple intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies consistent with Henderson-Patterson bodies. The diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Molluscum contagiosum

 

Clinical history along with histological image showing intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies suggests a diagnosis of Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a poxvirus infection of the skin and the mucous membranes.

 

There are four types of molluscum contagiosum viruses (MCVs), MCV-1 to -4, with MCV-1 being the most prevalent and MCV-2 being most often sexually transmitted.

 

The infections are common in young children between 2 and 12 years of age and are transmitted through direct contact or shared articles (e.g., towels).

 

Molluscum may affect any area of the skin but is most common on the trunk, arms, and legs. In adults, molluscum infections are typically sexually transmitted and affect the genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs.

 

The average incubation period is 6 weeks.

 

Diagnosis is based on the characteristic clinical appearance of pearly, domeshaped papules with a dimpled center. The papules measure 1 to 5 mm in diameter, and their central waxy core contains cells with intracytoplasmic viral inclusions called as Molluscum bodies or Henderson Patterson bodies.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trichodysplasia spinulosa: This is a rare viral infection associated with immunosuppression and does not typically present with the described clinical or histopathological features.

 

Option B. Condyloma accuminata: Caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), this condition presents as warty growths, typically on the genital and perianal regions, but it does not produce Henderson-Patterson bodies.

 

Option D. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, this sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis presents with ulcerative lesions rather than nodular papules and does not show the characteristic Henderson-Patterson bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection that presents with dome-shaped papules containing Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are diagnostic of this condition.

questions.text: There was outbreak of MRSA in the hospital, and it was found that a nurse of NICU had MRSA colonization of anterior nares. What is the best treatment?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Topical mupirocin

 

  • Anterior nares are the most common site of colonization in carrier state of MRSA.
  • Mupirocin (2% topical cream) is DOC for MRSA carriers. Other drug that can be used is topical Bacitracin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral Vancomycin: Vancomycin is typically used for systemic MRSA infections and is administered intravenously due to poor oral absorption. It is not appropriate for eradicating nasal colonization.

 

Option C. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is used for multi-drug-resistant gram-negative infections and is not indicated for MRSA, especially not for nasal colonization.

 

Option D. IV cefazolin: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin effective against methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) but not MRSA. It is also not suitable for treating nasal colonization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For MRSA colonization in the anterior nares, topical mupirocin is the best treatment due to its targeted action, efficacy, and minimal systemic side effects.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/809

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of exudative pleural effusion? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rheumatoid arthritis

 

Why Rheumatoid Arthritis is Correct: Rheumatoid arthritis is an inflammatory condition that can lead to the accumulation of exudative pleural effusion. Exudative effusions are characterized by high protein content and cellular debris resulting from increased capillary permeability typically due to inflammation or injury to the pleural membranes.

 

The diagnosis of an exudative pleural effusion is confirmed using Light's criteria, which states that a pleural effusion is exudative if at least one of the following is true:

 

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio > 0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio > 0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH more than two-thirds the upper limit of normal serum LDH

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heart failure: Heart failure typically causes a transudative pleural effusion, which results from increased hydrostatic pressure or decreased oncotic pressure without inflammation. The pleural fluid in transudative effusions has low protein content and is generally less cellular.

 

Heart failure is currently the most common cause of pleural effusion (MC cause of transudative pleural effusion).

 

Option B. Liver failure: Liver failure leads to a transudative pleural effusion due to the accumulation of fluid in the abdomen (ascites) that moves into the pleural space, also known as hepatic hydrothorax. This is due to the RAS-activated state causing low protein content in the effusion.

 

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome: Nephrotic syndrome causes a transudative pleural effusion. The loss of protein in the urine leads to low serum albumin levels and decreased oncotic pressure, resulting in fluid accumulation in the pleural space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exudative pleural effusions are typically caused by conditions that involve inflammation or injury to the pleura, such as rheumatoid arthritis, while transudative effusions are usually due to systemic conditions like heart failure, liver failure, and nephrotic syndrome that affect hydrostatic or oncotic pressure.

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

 

The classical presentation is described as the 6 P's of congenital hypothyroidism: pot-belly, pale, puffy-faced child with protruding umbilicus, protuberant tongue, and poor brain development and persistent opening of posterior fontanelle, prolong jaundice & hypotonia.

 

The given laboratory finding of increased thyroid-stimulating hormone level in an 8-day-old baby is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Radiotracer uptake with technetium will be the next investigation in this condition to confirm the presence of the thyroid gland.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine iodine excretion: This test measures the iodine content in urine and is typically used to assess iodine deficiency in populations rather than diagnosing congenital hypothyroidism in an individual.

 

Option B. Serum thyroid receptor antibody: This test is more relevant in diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases such as Graves' disease rather than congenital hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Perchlorate secretion test: This test is used to identify a defect in thyroid hormone synthesis, particularly in conditions like thyroid dyshormonogenesis, but it is not the first-line investigation for a neonate with high TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever and nuchal rigidity. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h
  2. Start injection ceftriaxone
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis
  4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

 

When managing a patient with fever and nuchal rigidity (suggesting possible meningitis), the correct order of steps is:

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h: Establishing IV access is the first priority to ensure hydration and create a route for medication administration.
  2. 4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture: The lumbar puncture should be performed early to collect CSF samples before antimicrobial therapy alters the CSF findings.
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis: Once the CSF is collected, it must be promptly sent for laboratory analysis to identify potential pathogens and guide targeted therapy.
  4. Start injection ceftriaxone: After CSF collection, empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone should be initiated. This ensures that treatment doesn't interfere with CSF culture results while still providing timely antimicrobial coverage.

 

This sequence prioritizes obtaining diagnostic samples before starting antimicrobial therapy, which is critical for accurate diagnosis while not unduly delaying treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected meningitis, the ideal sequence is to secure samples for microbiological diagnosis before starting antibiotics, when clinically feasible. However, if there will be a significant delay in performing the lumbar puncture or if the patient is critically ill, antibiotics should not be delayed. The sequence emphasizes balancing the need for accurate diagnosis with timely intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a widespread disease caused by a tick-borne virus (Nairovirus) of the Bunyaviridae family. The CCHF virus causes severe viral haemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10–40%.

 

CCHF is endemic in Africa, the Balkans, the Middle East and Asian countries south of the 50th parallel north – the geographical limit of the principal tick vector. Outbreak in Gujarat, India occurred in 2011.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow fever is mostly endemic to the south and central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Option C. Ebola virus is located mainly in sub-Saharan Africa

 

Option D. Hendra virus mainly confined to north-eastern coast of Australia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been reported to have endemic transmission in India, specifically with an outbreak in Gujarat in 2011.

questions.text: The farmer presents with a cauliflower-like mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury, as depicted in the image. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of copper penny bodies. Based on this information, what is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chromoblastomycosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is chromoblastomycosis.

 

Chromoblastomycosis:

 

  • Causative Organism:  Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora species.
  • Clinical features: The initial presentation consists of warty papules that gradually enlarge, forming a hypertrophic plaque resembling cauliflower. Over the course of months to years, these lesions progress to large, hyperkeratotic masses with a surface often speckled with black dots.

 

 

Histopathology: Foreign body granuloma & Sclerotic / Medlar / Copper penny /Muriform bodies.

 

Treatment: Itraconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomycosis:

  • Caused by the fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis.
  • It primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other parts of the body, including the skin.
  • Skin manifestations can be ulcerative or verrucous but the presence of "copper penny bodies" is not a characteristic feature of this infection.
  • Thus, the microscopic finding does not match this option.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis/Rose Gardeners disease.

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear noduloulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in

 

  • FISH TANK/SWIMMING POOL GRANULOMA
  • LUPUS VULGARIS.

 

The given images show the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology:  Asteroid bodies are seen.


Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Option D. Phaeohyphomycosis:

  • Represents a group of infections caused by various dematiaceous fungi.
  • Lesions can vary in appearance from nodules to cysts or abscesses.
  • Unlike chromoblastomycosis, phaeohyphomycosis does not characteristically have sclerotic or "copper penny" bodies under the microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its clinical presentation of verrucous skin lesions and the histopathological finding of sclerotic or copper penny bodies, indicative of infection with dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: Which of the following is inhalational anesthetic of choice for pediatric age group? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the inhalational anesthetic of choice for pediatric patients.

 

Key Points about Sevoflurane:

 

  • Sweet Smelling: Sevoflurane has a pleasant, non-irritating odor, making it easier for children to tolerate during induction.
  • Rapid Onset and Offset: Sevoflurane has a low blood-gas partition coefficient, leading to rapid induction and recovery, which is ideal for pediatric anesthesia.
  • Safety Profile: It has a relatively favorable safety profile for use in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: Halothane was once widely used in pediatric anesthesia but is now less favored due to its potential for causing arrhythmias and hepatotoxicity.

 

Option B. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is effective but has a pungent odor and can be irritating to the respiratory tract, making it less suitable for pediatric induction.

 

Option D. Desflurane: Desflurane has a very rapid onset and offset but is highly pungent and can cause airway irritation, making it less suitable for children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational anesthetic for pediatric patients due to its rapid onset, pleasant odor, and favorable safety profile. It is particularly useful for inhalational induction, making it easier for children to tolerate the induction process.

questions.text: Which of the following connective tissue degradation disorder is associated with aortic aneurysm? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marfan's Syndrome

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that affects the body's connective tissues, which provide structural support to various organs and tissues. It is particularly associated with cardiovascular complications, including aortic aneurysms and dissections. This is due to the weakening of the aortic wall caused by defective fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein essential for the elasticity and strength of the connective tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: While Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) can lead to vascular complications, including aortic aneurysms, it is specifically the vascular type (Type IV) of EDS that is associated with these issues. However, Marfan's Syndrome is more commonly linked to aortic aneurysms.

 

Option C. Atherosclerosis: Atherosclerosis is a condition characterized by the build-up of plaque within the arterial walls, leading to narrowing and hardening of the arteries. It is a risk factor for abdominal aortic aneurysm but is not classified as a connective tissue disorder.

 

Option D. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, leading to defective collagen synthesis. While it results in symptoms like mucosal bleeding and poor wound healing, it is not associated with aortic aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder closely associated with the development of aortic aneurysms due to the defective fibrillin-1 protein affecting the structural integrity of the aortic wall.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester has a 2-year-old child. She received a complete vaccination course during her last pregnancy. What tetanus immunization is recommended for her now? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Td booster dose

 

As per National Immunization Schedule, the recommendations for pregnant woman are as follows: -

 

Td-1: Early in pregnancy

 

Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1

 

Td-Booster dose: if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For pregnant women who received the complete Td vaccination course during their last pregnancy within the last three years, a Td booster dose is recommended.

choices.text: Low TSH levels
Low free T4 levels
Low serum T3 levels
Radioactive iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Graves' disease. Which of the following statements would be correct with respect to her thyroid function test? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Low TSH levels
 

Grave’s disease in an autoimmune disease characterized by production of antibodies against the TSH-Receptor which stimulates the gland resulting in release of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) producing symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. Elevated T3, 4 produce reduction in TSH via negative feedback.

 

Other options:

 

Option B, C: Elevated levels of T3, T4 are seen in Grave’s disease.

 

Option D: Due to stimulation of the gland, there is Homogenous uptake on RAIU scan.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Graves' disease, low TSH levels are a key diagnostic marker reflecting the increased production and release of thyroid hormones T3 and T4, which exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland to reduce TSH secretion.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Grave’s disease/Chap 384

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.text: A patient post-tonsillectomy in the recovery room starts bleeding from the operative site. On examination, blood clots are seen. What will be your immediate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of reactionary hemorrhage post-tonsillectomy and the immediate management is to shift the patient to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the bleeding vessel.

 

Hemorrhage is a common complication of tonsillectomy. It can be primary, reactionary, or secondary:

 

  • Primary hemorrhage occurs at the time of operation. It can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or blood pressure returning to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. Ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels is done under anesthesia if the above measures fail.
  • Secondary hemorrhage is usually seen between the 5th to 10th postoperative day. It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Removal of the clot, topical application of dilute adrenaline or hydrogen peroxide with pressure usually suffice. IV antibiotics are given and the bleeding vessel is electro coagulated or ligated if bleeding continues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate return to the OT for direct intervention is essential in managing post-tonsillectomy bleeding. Ensuring the bleeding vessel is adequately addressed through cauterization or ligation can prevent further complications and promote healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 504, 505

questions.text: The scope of Project MONICA includes: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cardiovascular diseases 

 

Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases.

 

The WHO MONICA (MONItoring trends and determinants in CArdiovascular disease) Project was designed to measure trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease mortality and coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease morbidity, and to assess the extent to which these trends are related to changes in known risk factors in different populations in 27 countries (10 years’ period)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scope of Project MONICA is focused on cardiovascular diseases, specifically monitoring trends in coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease and examining the impact of various risk factors on these conditions.

questions.text:
Which of the following helps to differentiate a fixed dilated pupil? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Phenylephrine
  2. 1% Pilocarpine
  3. 0.1% Pilocarpine
  4. Cocaine 0.5%
  5. Epinephrine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only

 

Pilocarpine is used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils.

 

2. 1% Pilocarpine

 

 

3. 0.1% Pilocarpine

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. Phenylephrine: This is a sympathomimetic agent that typically dilates the pupil and is not used for differentiating causes of fixed dilation.

 

4. Cocaine 0.5%: Cocaine tests for anisocoria primarily in the context of Horner’s syndrome. It blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, failing to dilate a Horner’s pupil due to sympathetic chain lesion.

 

 

Note - Cocaine and 1% hydroxy amphetamine are used to evaluate anisocoria in smaller pupil.

 

 

5. Epinephrine: Similar to phenylephrine, epinephrine is not used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils but rather to induce dilation for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine at concentrations of 1% and 0.1% is crucial for differentiating causes of fixed dilated pupils, with 1% identifying pharmacological blockade or nerve palsy, and 0.1% detecting hypersensitivity in cases like Adie's pupil.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who is eagerly drinking water and skin pinch goes back slowly. Which category does the child belong according to IMNCI? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

The Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) is a strategy developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF to improve child health in developing countries. The child's symptoms of eagerly drinking water and a slow skin pinch return are indicative of some dehydration, which falls under the yellow category in the IMNCI guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green: The green category denotes "no dehydration." This would be for a child who shows no signs of dehydration and is otherwise healthy.

 

Option C. Pink: The pink category denotes "severe dehydration." Signs of severe dehydration include lethargy, unconsciousness, very dry mouth, and a skin pinch that goes back very slowly.

 

Option D. Black: This is an incorrect option as the IMNCI color coding does not include black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the IMNCI color coding system:

 

  • Green indicates no dehydration.
  • Yellow indicates some dehydration.
  • Pink indicates severe dehydration.

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 years

 

  • The X-ray shows 7 Carpal bones. Thus, minimum age is 5 here.
  • Also, pisiform is not seen. Hence, the age is between 5-12.
  • The best answer is 7 years as the normal age range for appearance of pisiform is 8-12 years.

 

BONE AGE

 

  • Left hand and wrist X-ray PA view – most commonly used for bone age assessment – Based on appearance of carpal bones
  • First to appear is Capitate, then in a counter-clockwise fashion except pisiform which is the last carpal bone to appear
  • Pisiform is ossified at the age of nine to 13 years as evident from different studies.
  • The appearance of ossification center of pisiform bone is one of the important evidence for estimating age among young children between nine to 13 years.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.

questions.text: What sign on day 2 would indicate a need for surgery in a patient who was conservatively managed in the ICU after grade 3 splenic trauma?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumoperitoneum

 

The presence of pneumoperitoneum on imaging would indicate a need for laparotomy as it suggests visceral perforation, which can lead to secondary peritonitis. Conservative management is usually recommended for splenic trauma, and surgical management is reserved for cases of hemodynamic instability or failure to respond to conservative management. Splenic angiography and embolization are also used for non-surgical management. The severity of splenic injury is graded by the AST spleen injury scale, and abdominal CT with intravenous contrast is the preferred investigation. A drop of 1g% of hemoglobin may be a physiological finding, and would not warrant a surgery.

 

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture can be managed with a urinary catheter, while distended gall bladder is a normal finding if patient has been nil per oral.

 

Grades of splenic trauma based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) spleen injury scale:

 

 

Pneumoperitoneum, the presence of air in the abdominal cavity, is a concerning sign and typically indicates a perforation of the gastrointestinal tract or another abdominal organ. In a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma, the development of pneumoperitoneum suggests a concomitant hollow viscous perforation and would likely necessitate surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoglobin falls from 11g% to 10g%: A drop in hemoglobin levels can be indicative of ongoing bleeding but may not be an immediate indication for surgery. It would typically be monitored closely, and the need for surgery would depend on the rate of decline and the overall clinical condition of the patient. Typically, a decline by >2g% Hb is suggestive of active bleed and warrants further management.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: While extraperitoneal bladder rupture is a serious condition, it is not directly related to splenic trauma. Its management involves keeping a per urethral Foleys and allowing the rupture to heal.

 

Option D. Distended Gall bladder: This is a normal physiological finding and does not mandate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum is the most concerning sign in a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma and would indicate a need for surgery, as it suggests a perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have polysaccharide vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are typically made from the polysaccharide capsule that surrounds certain bacteria. These vaccines are designed to protect against bacterial infections by inducing immunity against the polysaccharide antigens present in the capsule.

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant vaccine that uses a portion of the hepatitis B virus (HBsAg - hepatitis B surface antigen) produced in yeast cells. This vaccine does not involve a polysaccharide component as the hepatitis B virus does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal: The pneumococcal vaccine is available in both polysaccharide (PPSV23) and conjugate forms (PCV13), targeting the polysaccharide capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Meningococcal: Meningococcal vaccines also include polysaccharide (MPSV4) and conjugate forms (MCV4), aimed at the polysaccharide capsule of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option C. H. influenzae: The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a conjugate vaccine that includes the polysaccharide antigen from the bacterial capsule conjugated to a protein carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine, as it targets a virus that does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

choices.text: It acts as an alkylating agent
It inhibits polymerization of tubulin monomers in mitosis

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of cancer? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It inhibits dihydrofolate reductase

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate drug used in the treatment of various types of cancer. Its primary mechanism of action is the inhibition of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). DHFR is crucial for the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, which is necessary for the synthesis of purines and thymidylate, essential components of DNA. By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate leads to the depletion of tetrahydrofolate and ultimately inhibits DNA synthesis, cell replication, and cell function, which is particularly effective against rapidly dividing cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acts as an alkylating agent: Alkylating agents work by adding an alkyl group to the DNA molecule, which can lead to DNA strand breaks and cell death. Methotrexate does not work by this mechanism.

 

Option C. Inhibits topoisomerase II: Topoisomerase II inhibitors prevent the DNA from uncoiling and duplicating. Drugs like etoposide and doxorubicin work by this mechanism.

 

Option D. Inhibits polymerization of tubulin monomers in mitosis: This is the mechanism of action of drugs like vincristine and paclitaxel, which interfere with microtubule formation and function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate exerts its anticancer effects primarily by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, thereby blocking the synthesis of DNA and RNA necessary for cell replication.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anovulation

 

Explanation:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia. Menorrhagia refers to heavy menstrual bleeding that occurs in a regular cycle. In adolescents, anovulation, which is the failure of the ovary to release an oocyte during a menstrual cycle, frequently leads to heavy or prolonged bleeding due to the lack of a normal hormonal cycle that regulates the endometrial lining. Without the usual cyclical hormonal fluctuations, the endometrial lining may become excessively thick, leading to heavy bleeding when it sheds. This condition is typical in puberty due to the body's ongoing adjustment to hormonal regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, which can cause painful menstruation and potentially contribute to menorrhagia. However, it is less common than anovulation as the primary cause of menorrhagia in adolescents.

 

Option C. Malignancy: Malignancy is a rare cause of menorrhagia in puberty. While malignancy can lead to abnormal bleeding, it is not the most common cause in this age group.

 

Option D. Bleeding disorder: Bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease or hemophilia can cause menorrhagia but are less common compared to anovulation in adolescents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty.

choices.text: Assertion and reason are true and reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion and reason are true but reason is not the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion is true, reason is false
Assertion is false, reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion: Myocarditis is seen as a complication of diphtheria.


Reason: It is due to bacteremia.  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is true, reason is false

 

Explanation:

 

The assertion that myocarditis is seen as a complication of diphtheria is correct. Myocarditis is a well-known and serious complication of diphtheria, often leading to significant morbidity and mortality.

 

The reason provided, that myocarditis is due to bacteremia, is incorrect. The complications of diphtheria, including myocarditis, are primarily due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin (toxemia), not bacteremia. The toxin affects various organs, including the heart, leading to myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myocarditis is a complication of diphtheria caused by the diphtheria toxin (toxemia), not by bacteremia.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 Million Units intramuscularly

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of burning sensation during urination and a purulent discharge from the penis for the past 5 days. He has had unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner two weeks ago. On examination, the urethral meatus is erythematous, and there is a noticeable purulent discharge. A Gram stain of the discharge reveals intracellular gram-negative diplococci. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no known drug allergies. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cefixime 400 mg orally

 

The patient's symptoms, along with the Gram stain revealing intracellular gram-negative diplococci, strongly indicate a diagnosis of gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The recommended treatment for uncomplicated gonococcal infections, especially in cases of urethritis, involves the use of cephalosporins.

 

The drug of choice for gonorrhea is Ceftriaxone, typically administered as an intramuscular injection. However, in this case, an oral cephalosporin, Cefixime 400 mg, is a suitable alternative, especially if the patient prefers oral medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benzathine penicillin G: This is the treatment of choice for syphilis, not gonorrhea. The patient’s presentation does not suggest syphilis.

 

Option C. Metronidazole: This is used primarily for bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis. It is not effective against gonorrhea.

 

Option D. Doxycycline: While doxycycline is used to treat certain sexually transmitted infections, such as Chlamydia trachomatis and lymphogranuloma venereum, it is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cefixime 400 mg orally is an effective oral treatment option for gonorrhea, particularly in patients who prefer to avoid injections. The presence of intracellular gram-negative diplococci in a symptomatic patient strongly suggests gonococcal infection, requiring prompt and appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and the renal function is normal. He should be immediately started on pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 160/100 mmHg

 

  • The ISH (International society of HTN) 2020 guidelines were made to help decision making in low-middle income countries.
  • Presence of ASCVD risk factors, HMOD (HTN mediated organ damage) is an indication to start anti-HTN therapy.
  • Home BP recording helps in diagnosis of Masked HTN, rule out white-coat effect
  • ABPM provides 24-hour trend and fluctuations in BP.

 

 

Home BP > 135/85 mmHg = HTN

 

ABPM cutoffs:

 

  1. Mean Awake (daytime) average ≥ 135/85 mmHg
  2. 24h average ≥ 130/80 mmHg
  3. Mean Asleep(night) ≥ 120/70 mmHg

 

BP drops at night by (10-20%), morning surge – Steep increase, peaks in late afternoon.
 

Best observed in ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring):

 

  • Normal Dip: 10-20 % at night
  • Extreme Dip > 20%
  • Non-dippers < 10% (A/w Activation of RAAS)
  • Risers: BP raise

 

Note: Increase mortality risk among Non-Dippers and Risers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate pharmacological treatment for hypertension in patients without additional cardiovascular risk factors or organ damage should commence when blood pressure levels exceed 160/100 mmHg, according to the ISH 2020 guidelines. This approach helps to target treatment to those most likely to benefit from immediate intervention, balancing the benefits and risks of pharmacotherapy.

 

Reference: ISH2020, AHA2017 HTN guidelines

questions.text: What is the most common anemia in a 65-year-old female? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common type of anemia globally, including in a 65-year-old female. While it is true that menstruation is a common cause of iron deficiency anemia in younger women, older women can still be susceptible due to other factors.

 

In elderly patients, particularly in females, iron deficiency anemia can arise from a variety of causes, including:

 

  • Nutritional deficiencies: This remains a leading cause, especially in developing countries where dietary iron intake may be insufficient.
  • Gastrointestinal blood loss: This is a significant concern in elderly patients. Conditions such as peptic ulcers, hemorrhoids, and gastrointestinal malignancies (like colon cancer) are common causes of chronic blood loss, leading to iron deficiency anemia.
  • Malabsorption syndromes: Conditions that impair the absorption of iron from the gastrointestinal tract can also contribute to iron deficiency anemia.

 

The confusion might arise from the assumption that post-menopausal women are less likely to suffer from iron deficiency anemia due to the cessation of menstrual bleeding. However, it is important to recognize that other causes, especially chronic blood loss from the gastrointestinal tract, become more prevalent with age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of chronic disease: This type of anemia is common in the elderly, particularly those with chronic illnesses like rheumatoid arthritis or chronic infections. However, iron deficiency anemia remains the most common overall.

 

Option C. Megaloblastic anemia: This anemia is usually due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. While it is more common in the elderly, it is not as prevalent as iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option D. Pernicious anemia: A specific type of megaloblastic anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency due to intrinsic factor deficiency. While it can be common in older adults, it is not the most common cause of anemia overall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common type of anemia in a 65-year-old female, with causes shifting from menstrual blood loss in younger women to chronic gastrointestinal blood loss (due to malignancies) and nutritional deficiencies in the elderly.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with epistaxis. There was no relief on pinching the nostrils. Nasal packing was done but the patient still continues to bleed. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation should be considered in cases where epistaxis is not controlled by trotters method or nasal packing.

 

Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point.

 

Most common artery to be ligated for epistaxis is Sphenopalatine artery followed by internal maxillary artery, External carotid artery, Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligation of external carotid artery: The external carotid artery is a major artery that supplies blood to numerous facial structures, including the scalp, face, jaw, and more. Ligation of this artery is generally considered a more drastic measure and is typically reserved for severe cases where other specific arterial sources of bleeding have been ruled out or are inaccessible. It is much less selective than targeting the sphenopalatine artery and can lead to significant complications due to reduced blood flow to essential tissues.

 

Option B. Ligation of internal carotid artery: This option is generally not considered for epistaxis management due to the critical nature of the internal carotid artery, which primarily supplies blood to the brain. Ligation of this artery would pose a high risk of serious neurological deficits or stroke. It is a major artery and not a contributor to nasal bleeding; thus, it is not targeted in the treatment of epistaxis.

 

Option D. Ligation of maxillary artery: The maxillary artery is a major artery within the face that branches off the external carotid artery and gives rise to the sphenopalatine artery. While ligation of the maxillary artery is an option for severe epistaxis, it is less specific than targeting the sphenopalatine artery. The maxillary artery supplies areas broader than just the nasal cavity, including the maxilla, mandible, teeth, and parts of the face. Therefore, ligation of this artery is considered more invasive and has a higher risk of complications compared to the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation is a highly effective surgical procedure for controlling severe or refractory epistaxis after more conservative measures have failed. This approach targets a primary blood supply to the nasal cavity, significantly reducing the risk of further bleeding.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

 

The symptoms with the microscopic findings which shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci suggests infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment of choice for the infection is ceftriaxone.

 

Treatment of Gonorrhoea –

 

  • Third generation cephalosporins – DOC for uncomplicated gonococcal infection - both the sexual partners should be treated.
  • Ceftriaxone (250 mg given IM, single dose)
  • Cefixime (400 mg given orally, single dose)
  • If coexisting chlamydial infection – azithromycin or doxycycline added.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythromycin and Option B. Azithromycin are macrolides, generally used for chlamydial infections or as a co-treatment when chlamydia is suspected alongside gonorrhea.

 

Option D. Penicillin G is no longer recommended as the primary treatment for gonorrhea due to widespread resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially cases presenting with urethral discharge and identified intracellular gram-negative diplococci, Ceftriaxone remains the treatment of choice. This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

choices.text: Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day.
Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with previous history of Colle’s fracture is complaining of backache. Which of the following statement is false?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine. Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss. These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non vertebral fractures.
  • Prolonged used of Bisphosphonates has been reported with increased incidence of fractures of proximal femur. Hence, a patient on Bisphosphonates with hip pain requires X-rays to evaluate and diagnose these fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time. Teriparatide is a recombinant fragment of human parathyroid hormone. To preserve the increments of BMD acquired with teriparatide, therapy with an antiresorptive agent (e.g., bisphosphonates) should restart after teriparatide discontinuation. Bisphosphonates help retain BMD gains that tend to regress after cessation of teriparatide. Concomitant use with teriparatide is to be avoided because they may blunt its anabolic effect.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day. 1200 mg of calcium (total of diet and supplement) and 800 international units of vitamin D daily for postmenopausal osteoporosis are recommended.

 

Option D. Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation is a necessary adjunct to all forms of anti-osteoporotic therapies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year.
  • But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.

questions.text: What is 'mental retardation' now called according to the American Psychiatric Association in its revision of DSM-5? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intellectual disability

 

The term "mental retardation" has historically been used in clinical and diagnostic settings, but it has now been largely replaced due to its potential for stigmatization and pejorative connotations. In the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) by the American Psychiatric Association, the term "mental retardation" has been updated to: Intellectual disability (intellectual developmental disorder). This term is more respectful and emphasizes the abilities of the individual, rather than just their limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feeble mindedness and option B. Mental subnormality are outdated and non-specific terms that were used in the past.

 

Option D. Intellectually challenged is a non-clinical term that may be used colloquially to describe someone with intellectual disabilities in a more respectful manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's essential to understand that the term "mental retardation" is now outdated and has been replaced with "intellectual disability" in clinical settings, especially according to DSM-5, to ensure respectful and non-stigmatizing communication.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1118-1119.

choices.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prevention of RDS in premature baby

 

Explanation

 

Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4):

 

MgSO4 is used for several obstetric indications, including:

 

  1. Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of seizures in eclampsia.
  2. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: It is used prophylactically to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.
  3. Tocolytic in Preterm Labor: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractions and delay preterm labor.
  4. Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks): MgSO4 is administered to provide neuroprotection for the fetus, reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders in preterm infants.

 

Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in Premature Baby:

 

  • MgSO4 does not play a role in the prevention of RDS. Instead, corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or dexamethasone) are used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of RDS in preterm babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: MgSO4 is effectively used to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.

 

Option B. Prevention of Recurrent Seizures in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the preferred treatment to prevent recurrent seizures in women with eclampsia.

 

Option D. Reducing Contractility of Uterus: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractility and delay preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are used for the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm babies.

 

Ref: Page 1860, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory bronchus

 

 

 

The image shows a histological section of the lung with an arrow indicating a structure involved in gas exchange. The key features to identify include the presence of air spaces and the type of epithelium lining these spaces.

 

  • Respiratory Bronchus: This structure is part of the respiratory zone of the lung, where gas exchange occurs. It is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium transitioning to simple squamous epithelium as it progresses into the alveolar ducts and sacs. The respiratory bronchus is characterized by the presence of alveoli arising from its walls, indicating the start of the gas exchange process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar sac: Alveolar sacs are the terminal ends of the respiratory tree where clusters of alveoli are found. They are not the initial structures for gas exchange but are rather the sites where the alveoli are grouped.

 

Option C. Terminal bronchiole: Terminal bronchioles are the last part of the conducting zone and do not participate in gas exchange. They are lined with simple cuboidal epithelium without the presence of alveoli in their walls.

 

Option D. Intrapulmonary bronchiole: Intrapulmonary bronchioles refer to the bronchioles within the lung tissue that are part of the conducting zone and do not participate directly in gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory bronchus is the structure where gas exchange begins in the lung, identified by its simple cuboidal epithelium and the presence of alveoli arising from its walls.
